text: "Whether it’s Michelle Obama or, now, Amy O’Rourke, wives have long had to manage the home front while their husbands go out campaigning — and those husbands have been able to focus their energy on politics, knowing the kids are being taken care of."
author: NishaChittal

text: And candidates aside: society expects all women to be fully devoted to motherhood. Regular women are still chastised if they're not fully, 100% devoted to childcare. Dads, meanwhile, are assumed to be the secondary parent, the "helper." https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2019/3/14/18265471/beto-orourke-president-vanity-fair-amy-sanders?utm_campaign=vox&utm_content=chorus&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter …
author: NishaChittal

text: Women are not afforded the opportunity to be "sometimes" parents who "help" with childcare when they feel like it. A female candidate would be judged harshly for that. Read @annanorthtweets: https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2019/3/14/18265471/beto-orourke-president-vanity-fair-amy-sanders …

text: incredible tweet
author: NishaChittal

text: If you *really* want diversity at your company, don't just reach out to diverse groups to recruit for internships, fellowships, and entry level jobs. You should be doing the same for your most senior leadership roles, too.
author: NishaChittal

text: That's why so many of the leadership roles in media are still held by white men. Diversity recruiting often doesn't extend to those roles, because so many execs think there's only a handful of people who can do the EIC, SVP, etc job - and that they know them all already.
author: NishaChittal

text: A big problem with how a lot of media companies approach diversity efforts is that they think it's something you do for entry level jobs, but senior level positions are still recruited through personal networks and contacts. They rarely get advertised in the same way.
author: NishaChittal

text: A certain full-time freelance role making its way around Twitter today reminded me: people often tag diverse journo groups - NABJ, AAJA, @WritersofColor, etc -- when they're advertising entry level roles. But the same companies often don't seek diversity at senior levels.
author: NishaChittal

text: Listen, I have no sympathy for anyone here, but this detail is sort of heartbreaking?? text: The real scam is that college -- and especially elite colleges -- are only accessible to the wealthy!

text: "If the only goal of the college admissions process in America were to create a perfect educational environment for students — not to appease wealthy donors or boost the school’s brand through athletics — the fraud wouldn’t have worked at all."

text: Attn students: I went to a public state school in the Midwest. I could not afford any of these elite schools. My journalism career turned out fine. Yours will too -- you do *not* need to go to a fancy $$$ private school to get into the industry.
author: NishaChittal

text: Glasses are a racket. My optometrist's office tried to charge me $180 *just* for frames - and that's AFTER insurance. And that didn't even include the cost of lenses! Meanwhile I can get glasses at Warby Parker for $95 and that includes lenses and frames.
author: NishaChittal

text: It's no coincidence that AOC, Ilhan Omar, and Rashida Tlaib are the most scrutinized new members of Congress, the ones most criticized (and penalized) for what they say. America is still threatened by women of color in positions of power.

text: Friends from home often ask me how long I'm going to stay in New York, because it's assumed that everyone eventually wants a big house in the suburbs. No one believes me when I say an apartment and a no-car lifestyle in the city is enough for me.  https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2019/03/01/opinion/dream-home-condo-cloverdale.html …

text:
Also: people of color won 3 of the 4 acting categories tonight, for the first time ever. 

• Regina King - Best Supporting Actress 
• Mahershala Ali - Best Supporting Actor
• Rami Malek - Best Leading Actor 

#Oscars
author: NishaChittal

text: This year's #Oscars was the first time more than one black woman has won an Oscar in the same year. https://www.vox.com/culture/2019/2/24/18239135/2019-oscars-milestones-black-panther-roma …
author: NishaChittal

text: Everyone pretends they're so surprised when they win their Oscar, but the truth is they've been campaigning for months. This is a great piece by @alissamarie on how winning an Oscar is all about the campaign:
author: NishaChittal

text: Despite Hollywood's recent strides when it comes to diversity, "Aparicio’s newfound celebrity status is still considered extraordinary. In Hollywood, women like Aparicio are considered the exception, not the norm."
